The Act may be cited as the "Lavender Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017" or the "LOVE Act of 2017". During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, over 1,000 Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality. The Bureau of Diplomatic Security cited sexual orientation as a security risk, leading to discriminatory hiring practices. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department of State implemented a screening process to prevent the hiring of individuals who were perceived as gay or lesbian. This was partly in response to congressional investigations into the "sex perversion of Federal employees" and concerns about the presence of homosexuals sympathetic to Communism within the Department. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department of State reported on homosexuals fired annually. In the early 1990s, State personnel suspected of being gay were investigated and removed as security risks. In 1994, discrimination based on sexual orientation was prohibited, and in 1998, discrimination was barred by Executive Order 13087. In 1998, President Clinton signed Executive Order 13087 prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation in the Department of State. In 2017, Secretary of State John Kerry apologized for past discriminatory practices and reaffirmed the commitment to diversity and inclusion for all employees, including the LGBTI community. The Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources, in consultation with the Historian of the Department of State, will review employee terminations since January 1, 1950, to identify wrongful terminations based on sexual orientation. A report compiling this information will be made public within 270 days. Additionally, there will be reports on the reviews conducted. The Secretary of State will review the consistency of reviews conducted by the Director General under section 3 and submit reports to Congress within 270 days of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, a Reconciliation Board will be established. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on the "Lavender Scare" firings. The Board will contact affected employees or their families to inform them of inappropriate terminations and offer to change their employment records. The Secretary of State will establish a Reconciliation Board to review "Lavender Scare" firings. The Board will allow affected employees to change their employment records, provide a point of contact for testimony, and offer a grievance process for former employees who believe they were terminated due to their sexual orientation. The Reconciliation Board will review claims of "Lavender Scare" firings, allowing former employees to bring grievances if they believe they were terminated due to their sexual orientation. The Board will review each claim within 150 days and the Department of State will provide necessary information. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of the Act. The Board will review each claim within 150 days and the Department of State will provide necessary information. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF APOLOGY. Secretary of State Kerry apologized on January 9, 2017, for past discrimination against LGBTI employees at the State Department. He highlighted his support for the LGBTI community and efforts to promote their rights globally, including appointing a Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons in 2015. Secretary of State Kerry apologized for past discrimination against LGBTI employees at the State Department, acknowledging historical discrimination and expressing a commitment to diversity and inclusion. Congress also offered a formal apology for its role in policies like the "Lavender Scare." Congress offers a formal apology for its role in the "Lavender Scare" and similar policies at the Department of State, which were a response to congressional investigations into the "sex perversion of Federal employees" and reports on the employment of "moral perverts by Government Agencies". Establishment of permanent exhibit on the Lavender Scare. The Secretary of State will collaborate with the public-private partnership to create a permanent exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center. The exhibit must be installed within a year, provide access to relevant reports, and display material from oral testimonies. SEC. 8. GUIDANCE ON ISSUING VISAS.

The Secretary of State must report to Congress within 100 days on countries denying visas to spouses of Foreign Service personnel based on sexual orientation. Recommendations may include eliminating visa reciprocity with offending countries to ensure all spouses receive visas regardless of sexual orientation.

SEC. 9. ESTABLISHMENT OF ADVANCEMENT BOARD. The Secretary of State will establish an Advancement Board within the Department of State to address issues faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families. The Board will hear testimony on discrimination faced due to sexual orientation and submit reports to Congress with recommendations for improvement. The Secretary of State will establish an Advancement Board within the Department of State to address discrimination faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families. A report will be submitted to Congress with recommendations to improve the Department of State and prevent discrimination based on sexual orientation. The report will be private and accessible only to Members of Congress, their staff, and members of the Advancement Board.
